[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
- Object Properties: The object is the man's neck, consisting of soft tissue and bone. The neck mass can be estimated around 3-4 kg considering neck muscle and head mass partially supported by the body. The material is soft and compliant skin and muscle with some stiffness from underlying bone. Friction between the robot's gripper surface (likely rubber or foam) and skin is moderately high; assume a static coefficient of friction around 0.7 to prevent slippage during massage motions.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity acts downward on the neck and head, supported by the man's body and shoulders; the robot does not lift the head but manipulates skin and muscle for massage. The man is seated and stationary with some compliance in the neck and shoulder joints. The environment (table and robot arm) is rigid. Surface friction between the gripper and skin ensures stable contact.
- The relevant object is the man's neck, which has mass approximately 3.5 kg and with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.7.
- The surface of interaction is human skin with some natural oils and hair, providing moderate friction; assume a static friction coefficient of 0.6 to 0.7.
- Contact Types: Maintain a firm but gentle grasp around the neck, using a wrap or pinch grasp over the neck muscles and skin to allow controlled motions over a curved surface. Contact is primarily surface contact with some distributed force rather than edge contact. The grasp force is distributed to avoid discomfort.
- Motion Type: Composite motions including gentle grasping, small translational sliding (to simulate massage strokes), light tapping, and mild rotations (to knead muscles). Motions will be slow and controlled, arcuate strokes around the neck circumference, vertical sliding along neck muscles, and rotational wringing motions.
- Contact Considerations: Force along multiple axes is required to maintain grasp while performing sliding, pressing, and rotational massage. Normal forces must be sufficient to prevent slippage but not overly forceful to cause discomfort. Torque about axes perpendicular to the neck allow rotation and kneading.
- Motion along axes: The robot exerts a combination of linear and rotational motions in the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes, with primary linear sliding along +Y axis (along neck length), small linear motions in Z axis (pressing inward), and rotational torque about X and Z axes for kneading and rotating.
- Task duration: The massage should last about 120 seconds (~2 minutes) for a thorough procedure involving repetitive motions.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Neck mass ~3.5 kg, gravity force ~34 N, grip friction coefficient 0.7, contact surface friction ~0.65. Force to overcome friction negligible as no lifting occurs. Force must be sufficient to apply pressure ~5-10 N per finger area distributed without causing pain.
- Relevant equations: Force required to maintain grasp F_grip ≥ (applied force along any axis) / friction coefficient to avoid slippage.
- Relevant assumptions: Human tissue compliance reduces required grasp force; no sudden dynamic forces involved.
- Computations: For a linear sliding force of ~5 N along +Y axis, grasp force ≥ 5 N / 0.7 ≈ 7.1 N minimum to prevent slip. Similarly small forces for other motions. Applying grasp force ~15 N ensures stable contact.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 3.5 kg and static friction coefficient 0.7 along the surface: Since mass is supported by the man, robot applies gentle forces ~5 N for sliding, ~5-8 N total grasping force.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the neck's mass and motion requirements involving lateral adjustments, the robot must exert no linear force along the X-axis with magnitude 0 N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the neck's axis along Y and the massage strokes involving sliding along the neck muscles, the robot must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 5 N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to apply gentle pressure inwards towards the neck, the robot must exert linear negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude 3 N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon rotational kneading motions around the neck axis, the robot must exert angular clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0.2 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon minimal rotation around the neck's vertical axis, the robot must exert no torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon rolling and twisting motions gently rotating skin and muscles, the robot must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0.15 N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force: Estimated to be in the range of 10 to 15 N to securely yet gently grasp and maintain contact without slipping considering friction coefficient ~0.7 and needed force to manipulate skin and muscles during massage.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human neck, approx. 3.5 kg, soft compliant tissue with underlying bone, skin friction coefficient ~0.65, gripper-skin static friction ~0.7"
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Maintain gentle grasp with grasp force 10-15N; slide force along +Y axis ~5N; apply inward pressing force along -Z axis ~3N; rotational kneading torque clockwise about X ~0.2 Nm and counterclockwise about Z ~0.15 Nm; no motion in X linear or Y angular axes"
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [0, 5, -3, -0.2, 0, 0.15]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 12
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 120
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.

8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
